title: Newmark Capital snaps up Bunnings-anchored centre for $51m
text:
“We have seen a surge of interest from private investors in direct property since the Federal election and the subsequent drop in interest rates," he said.

"The self-managed super fund investor in particular relates to the Bunnings-based centres owned by the Hardware Trust.

"They like the secure rental which grows over time. The Trust is generally regarded as a defensive stock by investors, with the potential for capital growth seen as a cherry on top."

Since 2014, the trust has delivered annual total returns of over 14 per cent.

The Warragul centre includes nine tenancies and is 85 per cent pre-leased, including leases to Bunnings and Kmart.

The site settled in July and construction has commenced, with completion expected in June next year.

Mr Langford said the retail centre was located in an area of strong population growth, and only 40 minutes by car from Melbourne's eastern suburbs.

"[Nearby Pakenham] is going like blazers. It has the highest population growth in the state at 3.5 per cent per year," he said.

Advertisement

Big line-up

Newmark's latest acquisition is part of a big line-up of projects, including a planned redevelopment of The Jam Factory on Chapel Street.

The property fund manager, which Mr Langford runs with Simon Morris, manages a portfolio of almost $1 billion assets.

Its other assets include The Como Centre, Brandon Park Shopping Centre, Tooronga Village Shopping Centre and Chadstone Homeplus Homemaker Centre.

"The acquisition of Warragul is consistent with our approach to acquire well-located properties in strong local economies. The Hardware Trust focuses on Bunnings as the major occupier on long-term leases," Mr Langford said.

The Trust is paying a distribution yield of 6% with the potential for capital gains. The Trust presently has a WALE of 8.5 years and is 100 per cent occupied.
description: A 6 per cent yield is anticipated on the completed development, which Newmark purchased with development agreements in place with construction firm Troon Group.
